text: Hi, Deepak. Thanks for taking my call today. I'm Linda from Noodly. I'm really interested in learning more about your offering. I've been hearing good things about what you're doing. Hey. So Slack, I think would be, uh, great for you guys if you, uh... Actually, before we get into that, I wanted to understand what you're looking for. Well, we're having some challenges with our internal communication at Noodly. Our team has grown pretty quickly in the past year, and honestly, things are getting a bit messy. Information gets lost, people miss important updates. It's frustrating. I'd love to hear how you might help with that. And could I ask you what you're using for internal communication now? We're mostly using email, and we have this old messaging system. I forget the name, but it's really clunky. Some teams are also using WhatsApp groups, which isn't ideal for work stuff. It's all over the place, to be honest. I see. I see. And, uh, could you tell me, uh, what people use wh- Do you have anything in terms of a knowledge base or something that you can look up for information? Right now, it's kind of scattered. (laughs) We have some shared Google Docs and there's a wiki that hardly anyone updates anymore. The marketing team has their own system, and product keeps stuff in Notion, but there's no central place where everyone can find what they need. Sometimes I spend way too much time just tracking down basic information. I see. I see. So let me tell you a little bit about how Slack works and why, uh, personally, you know, we find S- Slack helps us to do a lot of things with a really simple tool. So, uh, to start with, Slack focuses on using chat as the primary way of communication. So texting, uh, is how you could think about it. So not so different from WhatsApp, but built for professional communication within your team, right? And so, uh, I think to start with, what's really great about Slack is just how easy it makes it to organize all your conversations, right? And it does this through a few simple, uh, tools that we provide that we found work really well, even for, you know, very large to very small teams. And, uh, Slack really started out as a product-led company, right? And people picked up Slack because it helped small teams communicate really effectively, right? So four or five member teams. I remember our own startup got started with Slack and used it till, you know, over 300 people and, uh, and continue to use it, right? The reason is that, uh, it takes your scattered email conversations and all the, you know, these really ugly looking threads and turns it into a lot more manageable interface that's easy to search and very real time, right? So, uh, primarily this works through one, of course, you can directly message people, but the other big thing is, uh, channels where you can create channels for any, uh, longer conversations, right? So you can have short term channels that are for a particular project for a week or two. You can have long term channels that, uh, you know, where you, for example, share updates on, uh, you know, sales conversations that are noteworthy for, you know, the whole product team to look into, right? And Slack just makes it really easy to organize all of this. That sounds interesting, especially the channels part. How do you handle making sure important information doesn't get lost in all these conversations? That's one of our biggest headaches right now. People miss crucial updates because they're buried in email threads. Yeah. So I'll tell you a few simple features that make this a lot easier, right? So now when, when it comes to email, it's typically... like especially when there are multiple people in a conversation, it could be 10, 20 even, right? Uh, sometimes even hundreds. Uh, it's very hard to, uh, cap- catch, capture somebody's attention. But when you send a message on Slack, you can just tag them and what happens is they get a notification, right? Now, uh, the thing with notifications is overload, right? So, uh, if you're plugged into, you know, 100 conversations, which we all end up being in, it's very hard to know which ones to look at and which ones you can, you know, postpone or even skip altogether. And these little tools make a big difference. So for example, if there's a, a, you know, a product and sales, you know, sync up channel where salespeople are, you know, asking questions about upcoming features or how a certain feature might work based on, you know, a query they might have received from a customer. Now, typically what happens with these channels is that salespeople post and maybe a couple of product people take interest, but generally, you know, the majority of folks are not actively looking at these channels because 90% of what's being posted may not be relevant to them, right? It's only one in 10 times that a feature that they're working on is being, you know, discussed. So what's... How Slack makes this easy is you can just tag somebody, right? So if you know that this is the PM that's working on this feature as a salesperson, I can tag them, or somebody else can also do this in a thread below, right? So once I put a message, somebody can...... uh, who knows who might be the right person to answer this query can just reply tagging them, and now that person gets a notification. And so, you know, your entire company is able to, in a way, massage this conversation to the right stakeholders. And once... and these features work in a, uh, in a sense, it's very, uh, uh, easy for people to catch each other's attention this way for relevant things, and it's easy also to ignore the rest of the things that probably aren't relevant to you, and then once in a while when you have time, you can go in and just scroll up the channel and check what's happening. So that's one way, you know. It helps people manage, uh, you know, these hundreds of conversations by actually just having to really look at only a few. And Slack has really great notification, you know, granular notification settings, so you can pick, uh, which channels you want to listen in to more, which channels you just want to be pull-... you know, get a notification when you are specifically mentioned, uh, et cetera. Right. Yeah. That's good to know about the tagging. In our current set-up, we end up having to forward emails or CC a bunch of people just to get the right person's attention. It sounds like this could help cut down on all that noise. How much training would our team need to get started with all these features? So the best part is that the whole interface is very intuitive. I would confidently say that you would need zero training for your team to pick up Slack and (clears throat) figure out, you know, really how it works without any handholding. And the cool thing about Slack is, as you use it more, initially, you know, you'll have 5, 10 channels. It's very easy to manage. Over time, you know, that number grows to 20, 40, 100, or even more. And, uh, as you get into those phases, you start unlocking, you know, more features that Slack provides to handle that granularity, right, uh, or handle, uh, this inflow of information in a way that allows you to still be effective in, you know, the limited time that you have to look at these things. Uh, and more than that, it's just super fun to use. (laughs) You know, it has all these quirky little features, like emoji reactions and, uh, fun GIFs that you can insert, and it really supports audio, video, images really well. So, uh, whether it's on your phone, on your app, or on, you know, your desktop client or on the website, we support all modalities, and, uh, I think it'll be a breeze for your team to get started. That does sound pretty straightforward. One thing I'm wondering about, we have some team members in different time zones. Would that be an issue with real-time chat? And what about storing important information that needs to be referenced later? Yeah, so when it comes to time zones, again, it's a thing that, uh, you know, we've also had to, uh, grapple with, right? And one of the ways we do it is, people, of course, can set their notification times and, again, have different levels, right, where maybe you are okay with taking a notification even in the middle of the night in a certain channel which is critical, (sniffs) right, if you're specifically tagged, but maybe not if it's just a normal message, right? So we give you all these controls to, you know, fine-tune these things, and, uh, it, it is really quite easy to, uh, get that going. And while Slack does support real-time chat and a lot of conversations happen that way, you don't... it... it's not that it doesn't allow you to, you know, hop back into a conversation later. So, uh, it's, I would say, the same way as WhatsApp, right? It is real time, but sometimes you don't reply right away, uh, and people understand that. Yeah. Got it. That flexibility with notifications sounds useful. I do have another question about data security. Since we deal with some sensitive product information, what kind of controls do you have in place for managing access to different channels? Yes, so you have, uh, uh, all the usual, uh, access control settings you would expect, right, where you can have private channels where only people who are specifically added can participate. You can also have channels that, uh, are open for people to join in if they like, and, you know, join and, uh, remove themselves as they wish. Uh, we also, of course, store all your information securely, and we're used by some of the biggest Fortune 500, so we, uh, definitely make sure that your data is private to you only.
